intro: Galium pseudopolycarpon, commonly known as the false whorled bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 13,000 species of flowering plants. The plant typically features slender stems with opposite, oval-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, white or pale yellow flowers are arranged in whorls along the stems, giving it its common name. Galium pseudopolycarpon thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
